content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: cool for Reverse

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Great for shortest. The examples are clear enough for a reverse. Good job!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nicely done puzzle, great for shortest.
the nice and fun problem for beginners

This is a fun clash of code! 
I think "The goal is to get the character in string at the index of toGet. The chars variable has a set of characters that each character represents an index of the string that you will get with the toGet variable." should be reworded. Perhaps along the lines of "The chars variable has a set of characters. The string variable is a given phrase. The toGet variable has a given character(s). The goal is to output the character in string found at the same index of toGet in chars."  

I do not think my rewording is the best either; but it just seems like something could be done to make it a bit easier to understand before even seeing the example. 

Question:
Should the variable name string be changed or shortened for easier and for avoiding the use of the word string by any coding languages?

Hope everything with this goes well !

All sections
* Please change all "char(s)" to "character(s)" where the word is not used as a variable name.

Goal section
* Suggest you to add a line break before and after the example to make it easier to read.
* Does the "Important" note still apply to any of the test cases or validators? If not, please remove it.

Input/Output section
* Similarly, if the "Important" note does not apply, please change "char/s" to "char" and "index/es/indexes" to "index".

Constraints section
* ≤= can be simplified as ≤.
* "there's" should be changed to "there is".

Thanks.

Thanks, you helped me a lot!
I changed what you said and added a test case that applies to the "Important" note.

Thanks, your reword was very good! I am Spanish, so I'm not very good explaining in English.
I changed the lines you reworded.
And I don't think is necessary to rename the string variable, because in languages that have a string keyword, automatically renames to _string.
Thanks again!
I was wrong, it doesn't rename it in all languages. I will rename it to "s".

You're welcome! And thank you glad I could be of some help. Ahhh okay. You did fine; English is my first language and I have enough trouble explaining in English myself lol.

And ahh okay. I am new to codingame so I was not for sure if it did rename it like that or not.

On that topic, I see that you missed one rename. In the example you left string as string instead of changing it to s.
